title: 107_hr2288
content: The Act may be cited as the "Asthma Awareness, Education and Treatment Act of 2001". The Congress finds that asthma affects millions of Americans, with a significant impact on children and school absenteeism. The prevalence of asthma has increased over the years, especially among low-income families and women. Asthma disproportionately affects low-income families, with higher rates in households earning less than $10,000 compared to those earning $20,000-$35,000. In 1997, over 5,000 Americans died from asthma attacks, with higher mortality rates among African Americans compared to Caucasians. The annual cost of asthma in the US is estimated to be over $12 billion, with increasing prevalence leading to higher future costs. African Americans have higher rates of seeking emergency care for asthma and face higher death rates, especially among children. Tailored treatment programs are needed for children with asthma as exercise can sometimes trigger negative responses in asthmatics. Grants are available for asthma-related activities in low-income communities. The Secretary of Health and Human Services may provide grants for projects in low-income communities focusing on asthma, allergies, and respiratory issues. This includes screenings, education, and workshops for individuals serving children in these communities. The Secretary ensures comprehensive screenings and referrals for asthma, allergies, and respiratory issues in various settings including medical facilities, schools, community centers, and government offices. Information and education on these conditions are also provided. Information and education on asthma, allergies, and related respiratory problems is provided in the appropriate language and cultural context. It includes understanding symptoms, prevention, monitoring, and managing conditions, such as avoiding triggers and knowing about medication. The importance of developing a treatment plan for asthmatic children to engage in physical activities is emphasized in various settings, including traditional and nontraditional ones. The evaluation of projects under this program includes determining the number of low-income children benefiting from it. The evaluation of projects under this program includes determining the number of low-income children and adults who have received screenings and referrals, assessing the impact on asthma prevention and management, and evaluating the effectiveness of information materials. A condition for grant receipt is that the applicant be a community-based organization serving the low-income community where the project is located. The Secretary may make a grant under subsection (a) if an application is submitted in the required form and contains necessary information. $8,000,000 is authorized for fiscal year 2002, with additional funding for fiscal years 2003 through 2006. The National Media Campaign to provide asthma-related information is authorized for fiscal years 2002 through 2006 with $8,000,000 in funding. The Secretary of Health and Human Services may award contracts for a national media campaign on asthma, allergies, and respiratory problems, with a focus on children. $5,000,000 is allocated for this campaign, which must provide information on prevention and management of these conditions. The campaign on asthma, allergies, and respiratory problems aims to provide information, screenings, referrals, and treatment in a culturally appropriate manner. It should have universal appeal and may receive $600,000 for fiscal year 2002, with additional funding for subsequent years. Qualified services include pest control and HVAC services. Taxpayers can claim a donation credit for providing pest control or HVAC services in public housing or low-income multifamily residential properties to address asthma or allergy triggers. Services must be part of a good faith effort to locate and remedy indoor air quality problems. Services must include eliminating pests, indoor allergens, and improving indoor air quality through heating, ventilation, and air conditioning services. The amendment adds a new paragraph allowing taxpayers in pest control or climate control services to claim a donation credit under section 45G. Additionally, it specifies that the section 45G credit cannot be carried back before January 1, 2002. The amendment allows taxpayers in pest control or climate control services to claim a donation credit under section 45G, which cannot be carried back before January 1, 2002. The amendment allows taxpayers to claim a donation credit for pest control and climate control services under section 45G of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, effective for taxable years starting after December 31, 2001. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will implement a program to raise awareness about this initiative, and there will be research on the link between air pollutants and asthma-related issues. The Secretary of Health and Human Services, in consultation with the EPA, will conduct research to determine the link between air pollutants and asthma, allergies, and respiratory problems. Clinical research will prioritize individuals for clinical evaluations. The paragraph refers to individuals residing in communities with family incomes at or below 200 percent of the poverty line. SEC. 8. COORDINATION OF FEDERAL ACTIVITIES TO ADDRESS ASTHMA-RELATED HEALTH CARE NEEDS. The Director of the National Heart, Lung, and Blood Institute will identify federal programs for asthma, develop a federal response plan, and submit recommendations to Congress. The Department of Housing and Urban Development will have a representative on the coordinating committee. The National Asthma Education Prevention Program will receive $5,000,000 from the National Institutes of Health for fiscal years 2002 through 2006 to carry out its tasks. This funding is in addition to any other appropriations for the program during this period. SEC. 9. COMPILATION OF DATA BY CENTERS FOR DISEASE CONTROL AND PREVENTION. The Director of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, in consultation with the National Asthma Education Prevention Program Coordinating Committee, conducts local asthma surveillance activities to collect data on asthma prevalence, severity, and management. This includes telephone surveys and health care facility surveillance. They also compile and publish data on the prevalence of children with asthma and childhood mortality rates associated with asthma nationally and by state.
